title: Own the keys, own your data
body:
![You own the keys1](https://akord.com/media/you_own_the_keys1.png)

With Akord, you own the keys that encrypt and decrypt your data. Your keys are generated when you sign up and are represented by your backup phrase. In this article article, we'll explain the backup phrase, how we store and manage it, and demonstrate exactly how you 'own the keys'.

## Your backup phrase explained

For many web3 services, the backup phrase is required any time you would like to access your wallet from a new device. Let's first explain what the backup phrase is.

In order to generate unique keys, we need a unique random number that is known as a “seed”. Since it is difficult for us to read a large number, crypto-wallets use a backup phrase, which is a human-readable representation of the seed. It is also known by other names such as seed phrase, recovery phrase, mnemonic, or passphrase.

The backup phrase is typically generated using an algorithm called [BIP39](https://privacypros.io/wallets/mnemonic-phrase) and assigned to a user when signing up. Akord uses this method to generate the backup phrase. It consists of 12 or 24 words that are chosen from a list of [2,048 words](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/blob/master/bip-0039/english.txt) beginning with “abandon” and ending with “zoo”.

How safe is a backup phrase that is made up of 12 words? Well, since there are plenty of possible combinations, the chance of drawing the right combination is 1 out of the big number below:

2,048^12 = 5444517870735015415413993718908291383296 ≈ 5.4445179e+39

So, as you can see, backup phrase is pretty much impossible to hack from a brute force attack that tries to guess what your backup phrase is. You just need to store it in a safe place.

We recommend the following security practices:

* Store your backup phrase in a few different secure locations offline.
* Don’t communicate your backup phrase to anyone.
* Don’t store your backup phrase unencrypted digitally.

## You own the backup phrase on Akord

In Akord, we ask for an email address and password. We ask for your email so we can send you important notifications when other people in your vault take actions. Your password is used to decrypt your backup phrase locally when you want to sign in.

The backup phrase is encrypted using your actual password. This means that nobody can decrypt your backup phrase without knowing your password.

We store the following three things in our database:

1. E-mail address
2. Encrypted backup phrase
3. Verifier of the password

We do not store your password, but rather a cryptographic verifier of it. This means that we can easily check if a password you entered is correct without ever seeing the password itself. For those who are curious about how this works in detail, you can read about this process in the [Secure Remote Password protocol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secure_Remote_Password_protocol) (SRP).

![Diagam](https://akord.com/media/diagam.png)

So here’s the process when you sign up with your email address and password. First, we encrypt your backup phrase with the password you entered, or more precisely, with a key derived from your password using [PBKDF2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PBKDF2). Then, we use the SRP protocol, to compute a cryptographic verifier: We send these two pieces of information along with your email address to our server. This makes it impossible for any middleman, or for anyone with access to the data, including Akord, to decrypt your backup phrase or obtain any information about your password.

## Akord’s simple sign in

Most web3 services require you to connect with a wallet, but with Akord you just need your email and password. So how exactly are you using your keys to sign in?

When you sign in, we first look up your email address and use the SRP protocol to make sure that the password you provided is correct, again, without actually sending the password. If the provided email and password are correct, we send back the encrypted backup phrase. It is decrypted directly in your browser, meaning that nobody but you ever knows it.

At this point, you're ready to use our user-friendly UI to upload your files to Arweave, with all encryption and decryption happening directly in your browser.

––

*We believe in true collaboration with the people using our product. If you have feedback on Akord, the best place to reach us is by becoming part of our community on [Discord](https://discord.gg/g4VXfauK5s).*

title: 熊市中如何低费用交互8个Layer 2龙头项目及应用？
body:
**熊市中如何低费用交互**8**个**Layer 2**龙头项目及应用？**

实测出一条对小白相对友好的，下午Gas低的时候，大约50U费用，就可以 串联8个不错的Layer 2 应用和赛道龙头的项目交互路线。

第一步：从FTX交易所提币ETH 到Arbitrum链地址，交易所支持Layer 2的Arbitrum地址提币（FTX交易所只要质押平台代币免费提ERC-20币）具体如图，很多做空投的ETH都可以从FTX免费提到各钱包地址，不管是交易打新还是撸空投建议一定要有这个交易所。

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Isgqz7N2UXdyskhoxdMxr.jpeg?height=716&width=800)

第二步：提到Arbitrum地址的ETH可以走orbiter.finance跨桥到zk-Sync，zk-Sync的空投是明牌，刷子应该不少，Layer 2的zk-Sync总体路线图进度是超预期的，主网测试一季度上线了，以前用Gitcoin捐款走过它支付的应该不陌生，费用很低 也可以体验下zk-Sync上铸造NFT。

第三步：ZigZag是Layer 2的zk-Sync上最大的DEX,之前关于ZigZag单独发过它的介绍，交易丝滑，费用低廉，建议用被动挂单费用更低，交易卡白问题很多是翻译插件的问题，切换到英文原本就可以了。

第四步：可以通过ZigZag的桥跨到Polygon，交互下Matcha和小狐狸钱包的Swap，注意交互的滑点和价差，这两个都是老项目了，还有之前的小狐狸的POAP还被炒作过。

第五步：走C-bridge跨链把币再回到Layer 2的Arbitrum，交互下Yield Protocol(固定收益协议)，这个也可以等后期奥德赛活动开启在进行～

最近Arbitrum奥德赛的活动推迟到下个月了，不然可以多走走Arbitrum的其他Dapp，顺便积累NFT。

以上是针对小白相对友好的一条路线图，当然你也可以用U，可以趁着下午的gas低的时候走一走，提币尽量有整有零，不要同时一起多地址做

有很多桥 体验并不是很友好，"卡 慢 丢" TVL数据也不是很好，再加上Hop原因 都给pass了，其他路线测试还在推进中，除了交互外还可以顺便拓展项目社群贡献，LP生态质押 ，NFT收集等，交互的额度越大越早越好，不要交互完了马上提币，做下币的时间沉淀周期等，尽量站在项目方角度思考发币问题

目前看项目空投发币共识已经形成多维度阶梯形趋势，或许简单交互只能拿个低保，所以尽量做精品号

很多项目方的最近进度问题，都可以去Discord去了解交流，目前团队成员在各个项目方社群都有OG贡献组身份，都是花一点点时间通过各种收集问题和为项目方提供解决方案，培育出来的～

考虑行情周期，币的情绪溢价等因素过去简单做交互拿空投暴利的时代已经过去了，弄不好还会被反撸，多思考多总结（DYOR）。
